thread.title: European Commission: Independent Scotland would have to join queue for EU membership
thread.title_full: European Commission: Independent Scotland would have to join queue for EU membership

author: Simon Johnson
title: European Commission: Independent Scotland would have to join queue for EU membership
text:
European Commission: Independent Scotland would have to join queue for EU membership An independent Scotland faces being outside the UK and EU Credit: PA Simon Johnson , Scottish Political Editor 10 February 2017 • 12:01am 
A n independent Scotland would start life outside the EU and be forced to join the queue for membership, the European Commission’s official representative in the UK has said in a major blow to Nicola Sturgeon’s Brexit strategy. 
Jacqueline Minor said Jean Claude Juncker, the commission’s president, had made clear there would be no more states admitted until 2020 – the year after the UK is expected to leave the European Union. 
She said there are several countries waiting to become member states, including Montenegro and Serbia, and an independent Scotland “would join that list.” This would mean Scotland being outside both the UK and EU for an indeterminate period. 
With the SNP’s leadership reviewing their stance on currency, she said a separate Scotland would have to commit in principle to joining the euro to get membership and show how it intended to bring down its huge deficit, which is even larger than Greece’s. 
Ms Minor also poured cold water on Ms Sturgeon’s plan for Scotland to stay in the single market even if the rest of the UK comes out , saying it would have to be proposed by Theresa May and there was “no precedent” for any such arrangement. 
Her intervention is significant as she has worked in various European institutions since 1984, spending 16 years in the directorate responsible for the EU’s internal market before becoming the EU’s ‘woman in the UK’ in 2013. 
It prompted Holyrood’s Unionist parties to challenge Nicola Sturgeon to start being “honest” with Scots about independence after she yesterday again refused to rule out a second referendum and claimed that she will “ensure that Scotland will not be dragged out of the EU”. 
Her government has attempted to ratchet up the pressure on Theresa May by stating that the Scottish Government’s desire for a special single market deal must be included in the letter the Prime Minister sends to the EU to trigger Article 50. 
Mrs May faces a choice between sending an extremely short letter merely notifying the EU, or to write a longer missive setting out her negotiating stance in more detail. Nicola Sturgeon refused to rule out a second independence referendum at First Minister's Questions Credit: PA 
S enior Nationalists have suggested that Scotland could negotiate a deal with Brussels to remain inside the EU if it voted for independence before the UK leaves in 2019. 
But Ms Minor, the Head of Representation of the European Commission in the UK, said Mr Juncker had made clear there would be no further EU “enlargements” during his term in office “so that takes you to 2020”. 
“There are a number of official candidate countries – Montenegro, Serbia, Bosnia, Herzegovina – they are still quite some way away from meeting the criteria for membership. And obviously were Scotland to become independent they would join that list,” she said. 
She acknowledged that Scotland “might” be able to gain membership quicker than the others as its laws already comply with EU rules but rejected Nationalist claims that it could seamlessly stay inside the European Union. 
Ms Minor said that was not the European Commission’s opinion during the 2014 independence referendum and nothing had changed since. She said Scotland would instead have to apply from scratch under Article 49 of the Lisbon Treaty, a process that can take many years. 
“Normal practice” is for new member states is to commit to joining the euro, she said, although she noted there could be “quite a lengthy period of transition to that status”. 
The most recent Scottish Government figures showed Scotland has a public spending deficit of 9.5 per cent of its GDP, compared to four per cent for the UK a whole and 7.2 per cent for Greece, which has been forced by the EU to impose extreme austerity. 
Ms Minor, who is stepping down from her post in the next few weeks, said Scotland would be forced to “come forward with plans” on how it intended to reduce this huge financial black hole. Protests in Greece against EU-imposed austerity Credit: Getty Images 
A lthough she did not think the UK Government would agree to Ms Sturgeon’s plan for a special deal, she said the other 27 member states would be forced to consider it if Theresa May changed her mind. 
But she expressed scepticism about whether this would be accepted by the EU, saying there was “no precedent whereby a free trade agreement has distinguished between significant regions of the partner country.” 
Adam Tomkins, the Scottish Tories’ constitution spokesman, said: “This is senior figure telling the SNP what it needs to hear. For all its moaning about Brexit, it knows fine well an independent Scotland would not simply step into the European Union. 
“It's time for the nationalists to be honest about Brexit, and stop using it as a tool to agitate for separation.” 
Lewis Macdonald, Scottish Labour’s Europe spokesman, said: “This is a hugely significant intervention from an experienced and respected official. 
“Now it's time for the SNP to be honest with voters - an independent Scotland would have to join the queue. Independence would mean leaving our biggest trading partner, committing to the euro, and even deeper austerity.” 
But an SNP spokesman said Ms Minor had “demolished many of the bogus arguments used by the No campaign in 2014 around EU membership.” 
He added: “We are focussed on protecting Scotland from the catastrophic effects of a hard Tory Brexit which would cost 80,000 jobs in Scotland over the next decade.” Follow Telegraph News
